hadiths.book_name_en: Fiqh Book attributed to Zaid ibn Ali
hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from Ali that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ prohibited leasing land in return for a third or a quarter, and the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: If any of you has land, then let him cultivate it or let him give it to his brother. When much land became uncultivated, they asked the Messenger of Allah ﷺ to permit them in this, so he permitted them and gave Khaybar to its people on condition that they tend its date-palms, water them, pollinate them and preserve them for half of the produce. When it ripened and the time for harvesting came, he sent Abdullah ibn Rawahah ﷺ to estimate it for them and give them their share from the half.

hadiths.book_name_en: Fiqh Book attributed to Zaid ibn Ali
hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from Ali that two men were partners during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. One of them was devoted to the market and trading, while the other was devoted to the mosque and prayer behind the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. When it came time to divide the profit, the one devoted to the market said: Favor me, for I was devoted to trading while you were devoted to the mosque. So they came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and mentioned that to him, so the Prophet ﷺ said: The one devoted to the market, you were only provided for your sustenance because of your partner's devotion to the mosque.

hadiths.book_name_ar: كتاب الفقه المنسوب لزيد بن علي
hadiths.book_name_en: Fiqh Book attributed to Zaid ibn Ali
hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from Ali regarding the two partners: Profit is according to what they agreed upon, and loss is according to the proportion of their capital contributions. Zaid ibn Ali said: Partnership is of two kinds, partnership of limited scope (inan) and partnership of absolute delegation (mufawada). The inan partnership is when two partners engage in a specific type of commerce, and the mufawada partnership is when two partners are partners in every little and much. Zaid ibn Ali said: Whatever liability binds one of the absolute partners binds the other. Whatever liability binds one of the limited partners does not bind the other, but he may recover from him in that if it was part of their trade.

hadiths.book_name_en: Fiqh Book attributed to Zaid ibn Ali
hadiths.english_translation: Narrated from Ali: There is no liability on a borrower nor on a depositary except if they violate the agreement, and there is no liability on one who shares in profit. The depositor may deposit the deposit with his wife, child, servant, or worker. Also, Zaid ibn Ali said: The pledged property is not to be benefited from by the creditor. If the pledged property bears offspring, the offspring becomes pledged along with the pledge to the pledger. Similarly, fruit from a date-palm is pledged. Pledging is not valid except when taken into possession, because Allah the Mighty and Majestic says: So take a bond (pledge) from them.
